{{short description|Canada's public film and digital media producer and distributor}} {{Use mdy dates|date=March 2017}} {{Infobox organization |name = National Film Board of Canada
''Office national du film du Canada'' |image = National Film Board of Canada logo.svg |image_border = |size = |alt = |caption = National Film Board of Canada logo |map = |msize = |malt = |mcaption = |abbreviation = NFB |motto = |formation = 1939 |extinction = |type = Federal agency |status = |purpose = Film and interactive media producer and distributor |headquarters = [[Montreal]], [[Quebec]], Canada |region_served = |membership = |language = English, French |leader_title = Government Film Commissioner and NFB Chairperson |leader_name = [[Claude Joli-Coeur]] |main_organ = |parent_organization = |affiliations = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = {{official URL}} |remarks = }} The '''National Film Board of Canada''' (or simply '''National Film Board''' or '''NFB''') ([[Canadian French|French]]: '''Office national du film du Canada''', or '''ONF''') is Canada's public film and [[digital media]] producer and distributor. An agency of the [[Government of Canada]], the NFB produces and distributes [[documentary film]]s, [[animation]], [[web documentaries]], and alternative dramas. In total, the NFB has produced over 13,000 productions since its inception, which have won over 5,000 awards.[http://www.nfb.ca/about/ About the NFB] The NFB reports to the [[Parliament of Canada]] through the [[Minister of Canadian Heritage]]. It has English-language and French-language production branches. ==Mission== [[File:Office national du film montreal.jpg|thumb|NFB headquarters (Norman McLaren Building), [[Montreal]], [[Québec]].]] ===Partial timeline=== *1939: The government of Canada proposes the creation of a National Film Commission to complement the activities of the [[Canadian Government Motion Picture Bureau]]. The legislation stipulates that the NFB was to “make and distribute films designed to help Canadians in all parts of Canada to understand the ways of living and the problems of Canadians in other parts.” Legislation also stated that the NFB would co-ordinate the film activities of federal departments. *1950: Canada's Parliament passes the ''National Film Act'', which states that NFB's mandate is "to produce and distribute and to promote the production and distribution of films designed to interpret Canada to Canadians and to other nations." This act also stipulates that the NFB is to engage in film research. *1965: As a result of a report written by producer Gordon Sheppard on Canadian cultural policies and activities, the NFB began regionalizing its English production activities, with producers appointed in major cities across Canada. *1984: Minister of Communications [[Francis Fox]] released a ''National Film and Video Policy'', which added two new elements to the mandate, with the NFB also tasked with being "a world centre of excellence in production of films and videos" and "a national training and research centre in the art and technique of film and video." *2008: The NFB announces a Strategic Plan that includes its first digital strategy.{{cite web|url=http://onf-nfb.gc.ca/en/about-the-nfb/organization/mandate/|title=Mission and Highlights|date=November 18, 2015|work=Website|publisher=National Film Board of Canada|accessdate=August 3, 2016}} ==Operations== The National Film Board currently maintains its head office in [[Saint-Laurent, Quebec|Saint-Laurent]], a borough of [[Montreal]], in the [[Norman McLaren]] [[electoral district]], named in honour of the NFB animation pioneer.{{cite web|url=http://saintlaurent.ville.montreal.qc.ca/fr/mairie/profildistricts/profildistricts.asp|title=Un territoire, deux districts électoraux|work=City of Montreal Web site|language=French|accessdate=May 16, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101107005909/http://saintlaurent.ville.montreal.qc.ca/Fr/mairie/ProfilDistricts/ProfilDistricts.asp|archivedate=November 7, 2010|df=mdy-all}} The NFB HQ building is also named for McLaren, and is home to much of its production activity. In the second quarter of 2018, the NFB is scheduled to move to its headquarters to the new Îlot Balmoral building located at Montreal's [[Quartier des spectacles]], adjacent to the {{Interlanguage link multi|Place des Festivals|fr}} square.http://onf-nfb.gc.ca/en/slider/nfb-headquarters-will-get-a-new-home-in-montreal-in-2018-2/ The NFB will occupy the first six floors of the building, which will allow it to have closer contact with the public, and will also feature expanded digital media research and production facilities.{{cite news|url=http://ici.radio-canada.ca/nouvelles/arts_et_spectacles/2014/09/25/007-siege-social-onf-montreal.shtml|title=L'ONF déménage dans le Quartier des spectacles à Montréal|date=September 25, 2014|work=CBC News|language=French|accessdate=September 26, 2014|location=Montreal}} [[File:Nm toronto nfb building.jpg|thumb|The NFB's offices in Toronto. The ground-floor Mediatheque was closed in April 2012.]] In addition to the English and French-language studios in its Montreal HQ, there are centres throughout Canada. English-language production occurs at centres in [[Toronto]] (Ontario Centre), [[Vancouver]] (Pacific & Yukon Centre, located in the [[Woodward's Building]]), [[Edmonton]] (North West Centre), [[Winnipeg]] (Prairie Centre), and [[Halifax Regional Municipality|Halifax]] (Atlantic Centre). As of October 2009, the Atlantic Centre also operates an office in [[St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador]].{{cite news|url=http://www.thetelegram.com/index.cfm?sid=297120&sc=88|title=Digital is the future of film, television, new media, says Tom Perlmutter|last=Wicks|first=Heidi|date=October 23, 2009|work=The Telegram|location=St. John's|accessdate=October 26, 2009}} In June 2011, the NFB appointed a producer to work with film and digital media makers across [[Saskatchewan]], to be based in [[Regina, Saskatchewan|Regina]].{{cite news|last=Chabun|first=Will|title=Generoux to helm reborn Regina office|url=https://leaderpost.com/entertainment/movie-guide/Generoux+helm+reborn+Regina+office/4848175/story.html|accessdate=June 12, 2011|newspaper=[[Regina Leader-Post]]|date=May 27, 2011}}{{Dead link|date=August 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Outside Quebec, French language productions are also made in [[Moncton]] (Studio Acadie){{cite web|url=http://www.onf.ca/selection/lonf-en-acadie-35-ans-de-creation/|title=L'ONF en Acadie, 35 ans de création|work=ONF.ca|publisher=National Film Board of Canada|language=French|accessdate=October 26, 2009}} and Toronto (Canadian Francophone Studio).{{cite news|last1=Yeo|first1=Debra|title=NFB's Ontario Studio gets new Toronto digs|url=https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/movies/2016/12/06/nfbs-ontario-studio-gets-new-toronto-digs.html|accessdate=December 16, 2016|work=Toronto Star|date=December 6, 2016}} The NFB also offers support programs for independent filmmakers: in English, via the Filmmaker Assistance Program (FAP) and in French through its Aide du cinéma indépendant – Canada (ACIC) program. The organization has a hierarchical structure headed by a ''Board of Trustees'', which is chaired by the ''Government Film Commissioner and NFB Chairperson''. It is overseen by the ''Board of Trustees Secretariat and Legal Affairs''. Funding is derived primarily from government of Canada transfer payments, and also from its own revenue streams. These revenues are from print sales, film production services, rentals, and royalties, and total up to $10 million yearly; the NFB lists this as ''Respendable Revenues'' in its financial statements. As a result of cuts imposed by [[2012 Canadian federal budget]], by 2015 the NFB's public funding will be reduced by $6.7 million, to $60.3 million. As part of the [[2016 Canadian federal budget]], the NFB will receive an additional $13.5 million in funding, spread out over a five-year period.{{cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/arts-community-had-better-spend-its-budget-money-wisely/article29358551/|title=FEDERAL BUDGET 2016: Arts community had better spend its budget money wisely|last=Taylor|first=Kate|date=March 23, 2016|work=The Globe and Mail|accessdate=March 23, 2016}} ==History== [[File:Albert William Trueman 1947.jpg|thumb|Albert William Trueman was NFB commissioner from 1953–1957]] In 1938, the Government of Canada invited [[John Grierson]], a British documentary film producer who introduced the term "documentary" to English-speaking film criticism, to study the state of the government's film production. Up to that date, the Government Motion Picture Bureau, established in 1918, had been the major Canadian film producer. The results of Grierson's report were included in the National Film Act of 1939. In {{start date and age|1939|paren=y}}, the Act led to the establishment of the National Film Commission, which was subsequently renamed the National Film Board (NFB). The NFB was founded in part to create propaganda in support of the Second World War.[[Ann Curthoys]], [[Marilyn Lake]] [https://books.google.com/books?id=JE6YM8jcRucC&pg=PA151 Connected worlds: history in transnational perspective, Volume 2004] p.151. Australian National University Press In 1940, with Canada at war, the NFB launched its ''[[Canada Carries On]]'' series of morale boosting theatrical shorts.{{cite web|url=http://www.filmreferencelibrary.ca/index.asp?layid=44&csid1=615&navid=66 |title=Canada Carries On |last=Morris |first=Peter |work=Canadian Film Encyclopedia |publisher=Film Reference Library |accessdate=October 17, 2009 }}{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The success of ''Canada Carries On'' led to the creation of ''[[The World in Action]]'', which was more geared to international audiences.{{cite web|url=http://blog.nfb.ca/2009/09/30/propaganda-cinema-the-world-in-action/|title=Propaganda Cinema at the NFB – The World in Action|last=Ohayon|first=Albert|date=September 30, 2009 |work=NFB.ca|publisher=National Film Board of Canada|accessdate=2009-10-19}} In this period, other NFB films were issued as [[newsreel]]s, such as ''[[The War Is Over (1945 film)|The War Is Over]]'' (1945), intended for theatrical showings. These films were based on current news and often tackled wartime events as well as contemporary issues in Canadian culture.{{citation needed|date=January 2018}} Early in its history, the NFB was a primarily English-speaking institution. Based in Ottawa, 90% of its staff were English and the few [[French Canadian]]s in production worked with English crews. There was a French Unit which was responsible for versioning films into French but it was headed by an Anglophone. And in NFB annual reports of the time, French films were listed under "foreign languages". Screenwriter [[Jacques Bobet]], hired in 1947, worked to strengthen the French Unit and retain French talent, and was appointed producer of French versions in 1951. During that period, commissioner [[Albert Trueman]], sensitive to how the [[Quiet Revolution]] was beginning to transform Quebec society, brought in [[Pierre Juneau]] as the NFB's "French Advisor". Juneau recommended the creation of a French production branch to enable francophone filmmakers to work and create in their own language.{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gM2j0CN64isC&pg=PA355&dq=Jacques+Bobet&hl=en&sa=X&ei=AdKhT8jMNdGcgQeNyZjfCA&ved=0CFAQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=Jacques%20Bobet&f=false | title=In the National Interest: A Chronicle of the National Film Board of Canada from 1949–1989 | publisher=University of Toronto Press | year=1991 | accessdate=2012-05-02 | author=Evans, Gary | pages=34–35 | isbn=0-8020-2784-9}} During the 1940s and early 1950s, the NFB employed 'travelling projectionists' who toured the country, bringing films and public discussions to rural communities.{{cite journal|last=Graham|first=Gerald|date=November 19, 2002|title=Five Filmmakers in Conversation with Gerald Pratley |journal=Kinema|publisher=University of Waterloo|url=http://www.arts.uwaterloo.ca/~kinema/nfb1011.htm|accessdate=2009-02-17}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nfb.ca/film/movie_showman/|title=Movie Showman|last=Spak|first=Harvey|work=NFB.ca|publisher=National Film Board of Canada|accessdate=2009-02-17}} ===Mandate revisions=== In 1950, a revision of the National Film Act removed any direct government intervention into the operation and administration of the NFB.{{cite web|url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/en/article/national-film-board-of-canada/|title=National Film Board of Canada/Office national du film du Canada|work=The Canadian Encyclopedia|publisher=Historica Foundation of Canada|accessdate=2006-08-30}} In 1956, the NFB's headquarters was relocated from Ottawa to Montreal, improving the NFB's reputation in French Canada and making the NFB more attractive to French-speaking filmmakers. In 1964, a separate French production branch was finally established, with Bobet as one of its four initial executive producers.{{cite web | url=http://onf-nfb.gc.ca/eng/portraits/260/ | title=Bobet Jacques | publisher=National Film Board of Canada | work=NFB PROFILES | accessdate=2012-04-29 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121018070118/http://www.onf-nfb.gc.ca/eng/portraits/260/ | archivedate=2012-10-18 }} In 1967, the creation of the Canadian Film Development Corporation (now known as [[Telefilm Canada]]) refined the mandate for the National Film Board. The Canadian Film Development Corporation would become responsible for promoting the development of the film industry.{{cite web|url=http://www.pch.gc.ca/progs/ac-ca/pol/cinema-film/pubs/epart3.htm|title=Canadian Film Policy: History of Federal Initiatives|publisher=[[Heritage Canada]]|date=January 22, 2003|accessdate=2006-08-30}} The [[Challenge for Change]] was also created the same year as a community media project which would develop the use of film and video as a tool for initiating social change.{{cite web|url=http://www.oise.utoronto.ca/research/edu20/moments/1966cfc.html|title=Challenge for Change launched, a participatory media approach to citizenship education|last=Schugurensky|first=Daniel |year=2005|work=History of Education|publisher=The Ontario Institute for Studies in Education of the University of Toronto (OISE/UT)|accessdate=2009-10-16}} Throughout the 1960s and 1970s, the National Film Board produced several educational films in partnership with [[Parks Canada]], including Bill Schmalz's ''[[Bears and Man]]''.{{cite book|last=Colpitts|first=George|title=A Century of Parks Canada, 1911-2011|year=2011|publisher=University of Calgary Press|location=Calgary|isbn=9781552385265 | pages = 153–169|editor=Claire Elizabeth Campbell|chapter=Films, Tourists, and Bears in the National Parks: Managing Park Use and the Problematic ‘Highway Bum’ Bear|url=http://dspace.ucalgary.ca/bitstream/1880/48466/17/UofCPress_ParksCanada_2011_Chapter12.pdf}} In the early 1970s, the NFB began a process of [[decentralization]], opening film production centres in cities across Canada. The move had been championed by NFB producers such as [[Rex Tasker]], who became the first executive producer of the NFB's studio in Halifax.{{cite news | url=http://thechronicleherald.ca/artslife/1211340-atlantic-move-part-of-nfb-s-history | title=Atlantic move part of NFB’s history | work=[[The Chronicle Herald]] | date=May 30, 2014 | accessdate=2014-06-02 | author=Cooke, Stephen | location=Halifax}} ===''Canada Vignettes''=== {{Main|Canada Vignettes}} During the 1970s and early 1980s, the National Film Board produced a series of [[wikt:vignette|vignette]]s, some of which aired on [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|CBC]] and other Canadian broadcasters as [[interstitial program]]s. The vignettes became popular because of their cultural depiction of Canada, and because they represented its changing state, such as the vignette ''Faces'' which was made to represent the increasing cultural and ethnic diversity of Canada. In 1996, the NFB [[operating budget]] was cut by 32%, forcing it to lay off staff and to close its [[film laboratory]], [[sound stage]] (now [[privatization|privatized]]) and other departments.{{citation needed|date=January 2018}} ===21st century=== In 2006, the NFB marked the 65th anniversary of NFB animation with an international retrospective of restored Norman McLaren classics and the launch of the DVD box set, ''Norman McLaren – The Master's Edition''. The NFB budget has since been cut again. The six-storey John Grierson Building at its Montreal headquarters has been unused for several years – with HQ staff now based solely in its adjacent Norman McLaren Building. In October 2009, the NFB released a free app for Apple's [[iPhone]] that would allow users to watch thousands of NFB films directly on their cell phones.{{Cite news|url=http://blog.nfb.ca/blog/2009/10/20/nfb-iphone-app/|title=What’s inside the new NFB iPhone App - NFB/blog|date=2009-10-20|work=NFB/blog|access-date=2018-01-23|language=en-US}} In 2010, the NFB released an iPad version of their app that streams NFB films, many in high definition.{{Cite news|url=http://blog.nfb.ca/blog/2010/06/30/the-nfb-films-ipad-app-is-now-available/|title=The NFB Films iPad app is now available! - NFB/blog|date=2010-06-30|work=NFB/blog|access-date=2018-01-23|language=en-US}} In March 2012, the NFB's funding was cut 10%, to be phased in over a three-year period, as part of the [[2012 Canadian federal budget]].{{cite news|last=Kelly|first=Brendan|title=CBC, NFB and Telefilm to see 10% cut|url=https://montrealgazette.com/entertainment/Telefilm/6382993/story.html#ixzz1qzGXr2EA|accessdate=2012-04-03|newspaper=[[Montreal Gazette]]|date=March 30, 2012}} The NFB eliminated 73 full and part-time positions. Beginning on 2 May 2014, the NFB's 75th anniversary was marked by such events as the release of a series of commemorative stamps by [[Canada Post]],{{cite press release | url=http://www.newswire.ca/en/story/1348609/new-stamp-issue-celebrates-the-75th-anniversary-of-the-national-film-board | title=New stamp issue celebrates the 75th anniversary of the National Film Board | publisher=[[Canada Post]] | date=May 2, 2014 | accessdate=2014-05-17}} and an NFB documentary about the film board's early years, entitled ''Shameless Propaganda''.{{cite news | url=http://www.bramptonguardian.com/whatson-story/4515216-documentary-reveals-nfb-wartime-propaganda/ | title=Documentary reveals NFB wartime propaganda | work=Brampton Guardian | date=May 12, 2014 | agency=The Canadian Press | accessdate=2014-05-17 | author=Kane, Laura}} ==Documentary== ===Cinéma vérité and Direct Cinema=== In the post-war era the NFB became a pioneer in new developments in [[documentary film]]. The NFB played a key role in both the [[Cinéma vérité]] and [[Direct Cinema]] movements, working on technical innovations to make its 16 mm [[synchronized sound]] equipment more light-weight and portable—most notably the "Sprocketape" portable sound recorder invented for the film board by Ches Beachell in 1955. Influenced by the work of [[Henri Cartier-Bresson]], the NFB's Studio B production unit experimented with cinema verite in its 1958 ''[[Candid Eye]]'' series. ''Candid Eye'' along with such NFB French-language films as ''[[Les Raquetteurs]]'' (1958) have been credited as helping to inspire the cinéma vérité documentary movement. Other key cinéma vérité films during this period included ''[[Lonely Boy (film)|Lonely Boy]]'' (1961) and ''[[Ladies and Gentlemen... Mr. Leonard Cohen]]'' (1965).{{cite book|last=Aitken|first=Ian|title=Encyclopedia of the Documentary Film|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JdSNAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA168&lpg=PA168&dq=NFB+cinema+verite&source=bl&ots=nOyhDgOKjX&sig=ntrnk-njA9xlm0EHn5Q2lwD8q7U&hl=en&sa=X&ei=bEl3Vc3KF4K_sQTh9JnwDQ&ved=0CFEQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=NFB%20cinema%20verite&f=false|date=October 27, 2005|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1579584450|page=168}} ===''Challenge for Change''/''Societé Nouvelle''=== {{main|Challenge for Change}} Running from 1967 to 1980, ''Challenge for Change'' and its French-language equivalent ''Societé Nouvelle'' became a global model for the use of film and portable video technology to create community-based participatory documentary films to promote dialogue on local issues and promote social change. Over two hundred such films were produced, including 27 films about Fogo Island, Newfoundland, directed by [[Colin Low (filmmaker)|Colin Low]] and early NFB efforts in Indigenous filmmaking, such as [[Willie Dunn]]'s ''The Battle of Crowfoot'' (1968).''[https://books.google.com/books?id=w2KVxcA2pcwC&printsec=frontcover&dq=%22Challenge+for+Change%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCUQ6AEwAGoVChMIs7nEve-FxgIVskOMCh2iQQAC#v=onepage&q=%22Challenge%20for%20Change%22&f=false Challenge for Change: Activist Documentary at the National Film Board of Canada]'' (2010). Thomas Waugh, Michael Brendan Baker, Ezra Winton (eds). Montreal-Kingston: McGill-Queens University Press., pp. 5-6 ===Giant-screen cinema=== NFB documentarians played a key role in the development of the [[IMAX]] film format, following the NFB multi-screen experience ''[[In the Labyrinth (film)|In the Labyrinth]]'', created for [[Expo 67]] in Montreal. The film was the centrepiece of a $4.5 million pavilion, which attracted over 1.3 million visitors in 1967, and was co-directed by [[Roman Kroitor]], [[Colin Low (filmmaker)|Colin Low]] and [[Hugh O'Connor (filmmaker)|Hugh O'Connor]], and produced by [[Tom Daly (filmmaker)|Tom Daly]] and Kroitor. After Expo, Kroitor left the NFB to co-found what would become known as [[IMAX Corporation]], with [[Graeme Ferguson]] and Robert Kerr. The NFB continued to be involved with IMAX breakthroughs at subsequent world's fairs, with NFB director [[Donald Brittain]] directing the first-ever IMAX film ''[[Tiger Child]]'' for [[Expo 70]] in Osaka, and with the NFB producing the first full-colour IMAX-3D film ''[[Transitions (film)|Transitions]]'' for [[Expo 86]] in Vancouver and the first 48 fps IMAX HD film ''[[Momentum (IMAX film)|Momentum]]'' for [[Seville Expo '92]].Aitken 2005, pp. 168-169 ===Alternative drama=== In the 1980s, the National Film Board also produced a number of "alternative drama" films, which combined documentary and narrative fiction filmmaking techniques.{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CJr5BJkGQoQC&pg=PA239&dq=Giles+Walker+NFB&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ZaItU8nMMYnTqgHXi4HwBA&ved=0CCwQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Giles%20Walker%20NFB&f=false | title=Canada's Best Features: Critical Essays on 15 Canadian Films | publisher=Rodopi | author=Stukator, Angela | date=May 30, 2013 | pages=239 | isbn=978-9042015982 | editor=Eugene P. Walz | chapter=Pictures of age and ageing in Cynthia Scott's The Company of Strangers}} Generally starring non-professional actors, these films used a documentary format to present a fictionalized story and were generally scripted by the filmmakers and the cast through a process of [[improvisation]], and are thus classified as [[docufiction]]. The alternative drama films were ''[[The Masculine Mystique]]'' (1984), ''[[90 Days (film)|90 Days]]'' (1985), ''[[Sitting in Limbo (film)|Sitting in Limbo]]'' (1986), ''[[The Last Straw (1987 film)|The Last Straw]]'' (1987), ''[[Train of Dreams]]'' (1987), ''[[Welcome to Canada]]'' (1989) and ''[[The Company of Strangers]]'' (1990). ==Animation== [[File:Norman McLaren drawing on film - 1944.jpg|thumb|upright|McLaren drawing on film, 1944]] {{Further|:Category:National Film Board of Canada animated short films|NFB Shorts}} When [[Norman McLaren]] joined the organization in 1941, the NFB began production of animation. The animation department eventually gained distinction, particularly with the pioneering work of McLaren, an internationally recognized [[experimental filmmaker]]. The NFB's French-language animation unit was founded in 1966 by [[René Jodoin]].{{cite news|url=http://www.animationmagazine.net/people/nfb-french-animation-founder-rene-jodoin-dies/|title=NFB French Animation Founder René Jodoin Dies|last=Milligan|first=Mercedes|date=January 28, 2015|work=[[Animation Magazine]]|accessdate=January 29, 2015}} ===Drawn-on-film animation=== When McLaren joined the NFB, his first film at the film board was the [[Drawn-on-film animation|drawn-on-film]] short, ''Mail Early''. He would go on to refine his technique make a series of hand-drawn films at the NFB during and after the Second World War, most notably ''[[Boogie-Doodle]]'' (1940), ''[[Hen Hop]]'' (1942), ''[[Begone Dull Care]]'' (1949) and ''[[Blinkity Blank]]'' (1955).{{cite web|url=http://www.mclaren2014.com/about_norman_mclaren|title=About Norman McLaren|last=McWilliams|first=Donald|work=McLaren 2014|accessdate=August 23, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151013005644/http://www.mclaren2014.com/about_norman_mclaren|archivedate=October 13, 2015|df=mdy-all}} ===Pinscreen animation=== The NFB was a pioneer in several novel techniques such as [[pinscreen animation]], and as of June 2012, the NFB is reported to have the only working animation pinscreen in the world.{{cite news | url=https://variety.com/2012/digital/news/nfb-pushes-canadian-artists-in-edgy-direction-1118054435/ | title=NFB pushes Canadian artists in edgy direction | work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] | date=June 4, 2012 | accessdate=November 10, 2018 | author=Blair, Iain}} ===Stop-motion animation=== McLaren's Oscar-winning ''[[Neighbours (1952 film)|Neighbours]]'' popularized the form of character movement referred to as [[pixilation]], a variant of [[stop motion]]. The term pixilation itself was created by NFB animator [[Grant Munro (filmmaker)|Grant Munro]] in an experimental film of the same name. In 2015, the NFB's animation studios were credited as helping to lead a revival in stop-motion animation in Canada, building on the tradition of NFB animators such as McLaren and [[Co Hoedeman]].{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/beta/arts/shaun-the-sheep-leads-the-stop-motion-animation-revival-1.3184267|title=Shaun the Sheep leads the stop-motion animation revival|last=Doherty|first=Mike|work=CBC Arts|publisher=August 8, 2015|accessdate=August 9, 2015}} ===Computer animation=== The NFB was a pioneer in [[computer animation]], releasing one of the first CGI films, ''[[Hunger (1974 film)|Hunger]]'', in 1974, then forming its Centre d'animatique in 1980 to develop new CGI technologies.{{cite journal | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xy09GvHqNRgC&pg=PA232&dq=Centre+d%E2%80%99animatique+ONF&hl=en&sa=X&ei=prTQT4DoIOaJ6gHn5rx8&ved=0CEAQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q&f=false | title=L'Office national du film et le cinéma canadien (1939-2003) | author=Zéau, Caroline | journal=Études Canadiennes | year=2006 | volume=10 | page=232 | isbn=9052013381 | publisher=[[Peter Lang (publishing company)|Peter Lang]]}} Staff at the Centre d'animatique included [[Daniel Langlois]], who left in 1986 to form [[Softimage (company)|Softimage]].{{cite conference | url=http://www.banffcentre.ca/bnmi/programs/archives/2005/refresh/docs/conferences/michael_century.pdf | title=New Media in an Adhocracy | publisher=[[Banff Centre]] | accessdate=June 8, 2012 | author=Century, Michael | date=September 29 – October 4, 2005 | conference=REFRESH conference, First International Conference on the Media Arts, Sciences and Technologies | location=[[Banff, Alberta]]}} The NFB was licensed by [[IMAX Corporation]] to develop new artistic applications using its [[SANDDE]] system for hand-drawn stereoscopic computer animation, with the NFB producing a number of films including ''[[Falling in Love Again (2003 film)|Falling in Love Again]]'' (2003) and ''[[Subconscious Password]]'' (2013).{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/behind-screen/siggraph-oscar-winner-chris-landreth-590998|title=Siggraph: Oscar Winner Chris Landreth Shows His New Short 'Subconscious Password'|last=Giardina|first=Carolyn|date=July 23, 2013|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|accessdate=August 18, 2013}} ===Traditional animation=== Traditional animators included [[Richard Condie]], John Weldon, Allison Snowden, [[Janet Perlman]], Cordell Barker, Brad Caslor, Michael Mills, Paul Driessen among others (some draw on paper rather than cels). ===Sand animation=== Caroline Leaf used this technique on films such as The Metamorphosis Of Mr. Samsa and The Owl Who Married A Goose. The Sand Castle was the first (and so far only) sand animation to win an Oscar. ===Paint on glass animation=== Wendy Tilby and Amanda Forbes perfected the paint on glass technique (mixing oil paint with glycerine) on films such as Strings and Wild Life. This technique was also used on Caroline Leaf's film The Street. ==Interactive== ===Works=== As of March 2013, the NFB devotes one quarter of its production budget to [[interactive media]], including [[web documentaries]].{{cite news|url=http://www.ledevoir.com/culture/actualites-culturelles/375392/l-insomnie-par-procuration|title=L’insomnie par procuration|last=Deglise|first=Fabien|date=April 11, 2013|work=[[Le Devoir]]|language=French|accessdate=April 15, 2013|location=Montreal}}{{cite news|last=Hutter|first=Kristy|title=A documentary like no other documentary|url=http://www2.macleans.ca/2012/01/18/a-documentary-like-no-other-documentary/|accessdate=January 19, 2012|newspaper=[[Maclean's]]|date=January 18, 2012}} The NFB is a pioneer in news|last=Vlessing|first=Etan|title=Expert: Canada Primed to Become Major Transmedia Player|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/expert-canada-primed-become-major-282926|accessdate=January 19, 2015|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} ''[[Welcome to Pine Point]]'' received two [[Webby Awards]] while ''[[Out My Window]]'', an interactive project from the NFB's ''Highrise'' project, won the technologist" responsible for NFB English-language digital content and strategy, based in the [[Woodward's Building]] in [[Vancouver]]. Jeremy Mendes is an interactive artist producing English-language interactive works for the NFB, whose projects include a collaboration with Leanne Allison (''[[Being Caribou]]'', ''[[Finding Farley]]'') on the webdoc ''[[Bear 71]]''.{{cite news|last=Mackie |first=John |title=NFB soars in cyberspace |url=https://199.71.40.195/vancouversun/news/arts/story.html?id=724c3bf7-176c-4594-85e8-90eff0199f8b |accessdate=June 11, 2011 |newspaper=[[Vancouver Sun]] |date=June 11, 2011 }}{{dead link|date=September 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{cite news|last=Moakley|first=Paul|title=Multimedia Heartbreaker: The National Film Board of Canada|url=http://lightbox.time.com/2011/06/22/multimedia-heartbreaker-the-national-film-board-of-canada/#1|accessdate=June 22, 2011|newspaper=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|date=June 22, 2011}} Dao's counterpart for French-language interactive media production at the NFB is [[Hugues Sweeney]], based in Montreal. Sweeney's recent credits include the online interactive animation work, ''[[Bla Bla]]''.{{cite news|last=Dixon|first=Guy|title=Bla Bla: An Arcade Fire collaborator gets into baby The plan also sees the NFB building on its relationships with Canadian schools and organizations to create more educational materials about Indigenous peoples in Canada.{{cite news|title=NFB launches plan to 'redefine' its relationship with Indigenous Peoples|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/indigenous/nfb-new-relationship-indigenous-peoples-1.4167947|accessdate=20 June 2017|work=CBC News|date=20 June 2017|language=en}}{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=Kate|title=National Film Board aims to bolster Indigenous staff numbers|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/film/national-film-board-aims-to-bolster-indigenous-staff-numbers/article35387705/|accessdate=20 June 2017|work=The Globe and Mail|date=20 June 2017|language=en-ca}} One of the most notable filmmakers in the history of the NFB is [[Alanis Obomsawin]], an [[Abenaki people|Abenaki]] director who will be completing her 50th film with the NFB in 2017.{{cite news|last1=Brownstein|first1=Bill|title=There's no stopping legendary documentarian Alanis Obomsawin|url=https://montrealgazette.com/entertainment/movies/theres-no-stopping-legendary-documentarian-alanis-obomsawin|accessdate=15 November 2016|work=Montreal Gazette|publisher=Postmedia|date=10 November 2016}} === Programs === ====Inuit film and animation==== In November 2011, the NFB and partners including the Inuit Relations Secretariat and the [[Government of Nunavut]] introduced a DVD and online collection entitled ''[[Unikkausivut: Sharing Our Stories]]'', makes over 100 NFB films by and about [[Inuit]] available in [[Inuktitut]] and other Inuit languages, as well as English and French.{{cite news|title=Inuit films move online and into northern communities|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/arts/story/2011/11/02/nfb-inuit-film-project.html|accessdate=November 5, 2011|newspaper=[[CBC News]]|date=November 2, 2011}}{{cite news|title=New NFB collection includes 24 films on or by Inuit|url=http://www.nunatsiaqonline.ca/stories/article/65674new_nfb_collection_includes_24_films_on_or_by_inuit/|accessdate=November 7, 2011|newspaper=[[Nunatsiaq News]]|date=November 4, 2011}} In November 2006, the National Film Board of Canada and the [[Inuit Broadcasting Corporation]] announced the start of the Nunavut Animation Lab, offering animation training to Nunavut artists.{{cite news|url=http://www.nunatsiaqonline.ca/archives/61103/news/nunavut/61103_06.html|title=Nunavut's getting animated|last=George|first=Jane|date=November 3, 2006|accessdate=November 8, 2011|newspaper=[[Nunatsiaq News]]}} Films from the Nunavut Animation Lab include [[Alethea Arnaquq-Baril]]'s 2010 digital animation short ''Lumaajuuq'', winner of the Best Aboriginal Award at the [[Golden Sheaf Awards]] and named Best Canadian Short Drama at the [[imagineNATIVE Film + Media Arts Festival]].{{cite web|url=http://www.onf-nfb.gc.ca/eng/collection/film/?id=57615|title=Nunavut Animation Lab: Lumaajuuq|publisher=National Film Board of Canada|work=Collection|accessdate=November 8, 2011}} ====First Stories and Second Stories==== In 2005, the NFB introduced its "First Stories" program for emerging Indigenous directors from Alberta, Saskatchewan and Manitoba. Twelve five-minute films were produced through the program, with four from each province. First Stories was followed by "Second Stories," in which three filmmakers from the previous program—[[Gerald Auger]], Tessa Desnomie and Lorne Olson—were invited back to create 20 minute films.{{cite book|last1=Knopf|first1=Kerstin|title=Decolonizing the Lens of Power: Indigenous Films in North America|date=2008|publisher=Rodopi|isbn=9042025433|page=64|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dNwFL-5b_9YC&pg=PA64&dq=NFB+%22First+Stories%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiK7OOA1NbTAhVM6YMKHaxgAiUQ6AEIIzAA#v=onepage&q=NFB%20%22First%20Stories%22&f=false|accessdate=4 May 2017|language=en}}{{cite news|last1=Sidsworth|first1=Adam|title=Cinema Revisited: NFB and the Indigenous voice {{!}} Toronto Film Scene|url=http://thetfs.ca/article/cinema-revisited-nfb-indigenous-voice/|accessdate=16 May 2017|work=Toronto Film Scene|date=1 November 2015}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{Cite web|url=http://onf-nfb.gc.ca/en/our-collection/?idfilm=57577|title=Second Stories - DVD|last=|first=|date=|website=National Film Board of Canada|language=en|access-date=2017-05-16}} ==== Wapikoni Mobile ==== The NFB was a founding partner in [[Wapikoni Mobile]], a mobile film and media production unit for emerging First Nations filmmakers in Quebec.{{Cite web|url=http://www.newswire.ca/news-releases/wapikoni-mobile-10-years-of-mediation-and-intervention-through-audiovisual-creation-514301541.html|title=Wapikoni Mobile: 10 years of mediation and intervention through audiovisual creation|last=|first=|date=|website=Canada News Wire|language=en|access-date=2017-05-16}} ====Early programs==== The Indian Film Crew was an early effort in [[First Nations]] filmmaking at the NFB, through its Challenge for Change program, and was jointly sponsored by the [[Company of Young Canadians]] and the [[Department of Indian Affairs]]. After five months' training about various aspects of filmmaking, participants worked on community development projects and research for future films. The unit's first release was ''[[The Ballad of Crowfoot]]'' (1968), described as "the first NFB film to present First Nations experience from an Indigenous point of view."{{cite web|last=Lewis|first=Philip|title=Fixing the Gaze: New Indigenous Work at the NFB|url=http://blog.nfb.ca/blog/2017/01/05/fixing-the-gaze-2/|website=NFB/blog|publisher=National Film Board of Canada|accessdate=4 May 2017|date=5 January 2017}} Subsequent films included the 1969 documentaries ''These Are My People'' and ''[[You Are on Indian Land]]''.{{cite book|last=Honarpisheh|first=Farbod |title=The Cinema of Canada|editor=Jerry White|publisher=Wallflower Press|location=London|pages=81–89|chapter=You Are On Indian Land|isbn=1-904764-60-6|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yc0bQ1-a8ZIC&pg=PA81&lpg=PA81&dq=%22You+Are+on+Indian+Land%22+Mort&source=bl&ots=HQn0z1SxH9&sig=uV1FfM4-NuvRaRoxrjEMhe8Stx0&hl=en&ei=pcYVS7DVFsO1lAfj7LzHBQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CCkQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=%22You%20Are%20on%20Indian%20Land%22%20Mort&f=false}}{{cite web|last1=Tracey|first1=Andrew|title=Now Reconciled: Nearly 50 years later, the director of a landmark First Nations film gets his rightful recognition|url=http://press.tiff.net/the-review/now-reconciled/|work=The Review|publisher=[[Toronto International Film Festival]]|accessdate=4 May 2017|language=en|date=24 February 2017}} A documentary was also made about the effort to increase aboriginal representation in filmmaking.{{cite web|url=http://www.nfb.ca/playlists/gil-cardinal/aboriginal-voice-national-film-board-/|title=The Aboriginal Voice: the National Film Board and Aboriginal Filmmaking through the Years|last=Cardinal|first=Gil|publisher=National Film Board of Canada|accessdate=2 December 2009}} ==Women's production== The NFB has been a leader in films by women, with the world's first publicly funded women's film's studio, Studio D, followed subsequently by its French-language equivalent, Studio des femmes. Beginning on March 8, 2016, [[International Women's Day]], the NFB began introducing a series of gender parity initiatives. ===Studio D=== In 1974, in conjunction with [[International Women's Year]], the NFB created Studio D on the recommendation of long-time employee [[Kathleen Shannon]]. Shannon was designated as Executive Director of the new studio—the first government-funded film studio dedicated to women filmmakers in the world— which became one of the NFB's most celebrated filmmaking units, winning awards and breaking distribution records.{{cite web|url=http://www.collectionscanada.ca/women/002026-714-e.html|title=Canadian Women in Film|date=April 12, 2005|work=Library and Archives Canada|accessdate=February 2, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070518224627/http://www.collectionscanada.ca/women/002026-714-e.html|archivedate=May 18, 2007|df=mdy-all}}{{cite news|url=http://www.montrealmirror.com/ARCHIVES/1997/082197/film4.html|title=Screen legend|last=Hays|first=Matthew|date=August 21, 1997|work=Montreal Mirror|accessdate=August 10, 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20021231170032/http://www.montrealmirror.com/ARCHIVES/1997/082197/film4.html|archive-date=December 31, 2002|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} Notable films produced by the studio include three Academy Award-winning documentaries ''[[I'll Find a Way]]'' (1977), ''[[If You Love This Planet]]'' (1982) and ''[[Flamenco at 5:15]]'' (1983), as well as ''[[Not a Love Story]]'' (1982) and ''[[Forbidden Love: The Unashamed Stories of Lesbian Lives]]'' (1992). Studio D was shut down in 1996, amidst a sweeping set of federal government budget cuts, which impacted the NFB as a whole. As of March 8, 2016, researchers and librarians at the [[University of Calgary]] announced an archival project to preserve records of Studio D.{{Cite web|url=http://ucalgary.ca/utoday/issue/2017-03-08/researchers-build-archival-record-feminist-filmmaking-canada|title=Researchers build archival record of feminist filmmaking in Canada|last=Sowa|first=Jennifer|date=|website=UToday|publisher=University of Calgary|language=en|access-date=March 8, 2017}} ===Gender parity initiatives=== On March 8, 2016, NFB head [[Claude Joli-Coeur]] announced a new gender-parity initiative, with the NFB committing that half of all its production spending will be earmarked for films directed by women.{{cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/film/nfb-pledge-for-gender-parity-could-spur-change-in-canadian-film-industry/article29083931/|title=NFB pledge for gender parity could spur change in Canadian film industry|last=Taylor|first=Kate|authorlink=Kate Taylor (novelist)|work=[[The Globe and Mail]]|date=March 9, 2016|accessdate=March 9, 2016}}{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/canada-bankrolling-more-female-directors-873546|title=Canada Bankrolling More Female Directors to Close Gender Gap|last=Vlessing|first=Etan|date=March 8, 2016|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|accessdate=March 9, 2016}} The following year, the NFB announced that it also plans to achieve gender balance by 2020 in such creative positions as editing, scriptwriting, musical composition, cinematography and artistic direction. As of 2017, 53% of its producers and executive producers are women, as well as half of its administrative council.{{Cite news|url=https://montrealgazette.com/news/nfb-aiming-for-parity-in-many-creative-roles-by-2020|title=NFB aiming for parity in many creative roles by 2020|last=Dunlevy|first=T'cha|date=March 7, 2017|work=Montreal Gazette|access-date=March 8, 2017|language=en-US}}{{cite news|last1=Dumais|first1=Manon|title=Place aux femmes et à la diversité à l'ONF|url=http://www.ledevoir.com/culture/cinema/493382/onf|accessdate=March 8, 2017|work=Le Devoir|date=March 8, 2017|language=fr}} ==Training== NFB training programs include: ===Animation=== Hothouse, a program for emerging animators that marked its tenth anniversary in 2015.{{cite news|url=http://www.animationmagazine.net/events/10th-edition-of-nfbs-hothouse-yields-8-shorts/|title=10th Edition of NFB’s ‘Hothouse’ Yields 8 Shorts|last=McLean|first=Tom|date=March 1, 2015|work=[[Animation (magazine)|Animation]]|accessdate=May 24, 2015}} Notable Hothouse alumni include Academy Award nominee [[Patrick Doyon]], part of its 2006 edition.{{cite news|last=Wyatt|first=Nelson|title=Oscar nomination sets bar high for Montrealer's second film|url=http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/Entertainment/20120216/oscar-nomination-patrick-doyon-120215/#ixzz1mYhlBdpX|accessdate=May 24, 2015|newspaper=[[CTV News]]|date=February 16, 2012|agency=[[Canadian Press]]}} Cinéaste recherché(e) is a similar program for French-language emerging animators. Past graduates include [[Michèle Cournoyer]], who took part in the program's 9th edition in 1989.{{cite news|last1=Morin|first1=Jean-Philippe|title=Une cinéaste de Saint-Joseph-de-Sorel lauréate d’un prix prestigieux|url=http://www.les2rives.com/culture/2017/2/15/une-cineaste-de-saint-joseph-de-sorel-laureate-dun-prix-prestigi.html|accessdate=March 8, 2017|work=Les 2 Rives|date=February 15, 2017|language=fr}} ===Theatrical documentaries=== A collaboration with the [[Canadian Film Centre]] on a theatrical documentary development program. First launched in January 2009, the program has led to the production of [[Sarah Polley]]’s ''[[Stories We Tell]]'', [[Yung Chang]]‘s ''[[The Fruit Hunters]]'' and Su Rynard’s ''The Messenger''. In May 2015, the CFC and NFB announced a new version of the program entitled the NFB/CFC Creative Doc Lab.{{cite news|url=http://realscreen.com/2015/05/21/nfb-cfc-team-up-for-creative-doc-lab/#ixzz3b6MAxiQi|title=NFB, CFC team up for Creative Doc Lab|last=Ravindran|first=Manori|work=Realscreen|accessdate=May 24, Chénier, formerly head of French Animation, is Executive Producer of Special Projects ===Former studios and departments=== ====Still Photography Division==== Upon its merger with the [[Canadian Government Motion Picture Bureau]] in 1941, the NFB's mandate expanded to include motion as well as still pictures, resulting in the creation of the Still Photography Division of the NFB. [[File:Cinema ONF.JPG|thumb|Montreal CineRobotheque, July 2008.]] From 1941 to 1984, the Division commissioned freelance photographers to document every aspect of life in Canada. These images were widely distributed through publication in various media. In 1985, this Division officially became the [[Canadian Museum of Contemporary Photography]].[http://www.collectionscanada.ca/inuit/054304-e.html "Photo Collections" in ''Project Naming''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070128131729/http://www.collectionscanada.ca/inuit/054304-e.html |date=January 28, 2007 }}, the identification of Inuit portrayed in photographic collections at Library and Archives Canada The division's work is the subject of a 2013 book by [[Carleton University]] art professor Carol Payne entitled ''The Official Picture: The National Film Board of Canada’s Still Photography Division and the Image of Canada, 1941-1971'', published by the [[McGill-Queen's University Press]].{{cite news|url=http://www.irpp.org/en/po/summer-reading-for-wonks/mid-century-lens/|title=Mid-century lens: The National Film Board of Canada’s still photos, 1941-71|date=July 2013|work=Policy Reality '' ==Controversy== In addition to ''[[Neighbours (1952 film)|Neighbours]]'', other NFB productions have been the source of controversy, including two NFB productions broadcast on CBC Television that criticized the role of Canadians in wartime led to questions in the [[Senate of Canada]]. In the early 1970s, two Quebec political documentaries, [[Denys Arcand]]'s ''[[On est au coton]]'' and [[Gilles Groulx]]'s ''[[24 heures ou plus]]'', were initially withheld from release by the NFB due to controversial content.{{cite book|editor-first1=Pierre|editor-last1=Hébert|editor-first2=Kenneth|editor-last2=Landry|editor-first3=Yves|editor-last3=Lever|title=Dictionnaire de la censure au Québec : littérature et cinéma|date=2006|publisher=Éd. Fides|location=[Montréal (Québec)]|isbn=2762126363|page=298|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kpPCydTC8IwC&pg=PA298&dq=24+heures+ou+plus&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiEh5XLub3TAhUG7YMKHal1A2oQ6AEIJjAA#v=onepage&q=24%20heures%20ou%20plus&f=false|accessdate=24 April 2017|language=fr}} ''[[The Kid Who Couldn't Miss]]'' (1982) cast doubt on the accomplishments of Canadian World War I flying ace [[Billy Bishop]], sparking widespread outrage, including complaints in the Senate subcommittee on Veterans' Affairs.{{cite news|url=http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0JSF/is_37_11/ai_87019610 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040924083230/http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0JSF/is_37_11/ai_87019610 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=September 24, 2004 |title=Paul Cowan's inquisitive eye: war games porn stars and the Ghosts of Westray |last=Alioff |first=Maurie |publisher=TAKE ONE |year=2002 |accessdate=August 30, 2006 }} A decade later, ''[[The Valour and the Horror]]'' outraged some when it suggested that there was incompetence on the part of Canadian military command, and that Canadian soldiers had committed unprosecuted [[war crime]]s against German soldiers. The series became the subject of an inquiry by the Senate. Other controversial productions included the 1981 film ''[[Not a Love Story: A Film About Pornography]]'', a 1981 Studio D documentary critiquing pornography that was itself banned in the province of [[Ontario]] on the basis of pornographic content.[http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/en/article/bonnie-sherr-klein/ "Bonnie Sherr Klein"]. ''The Canadian Encyclopedia'' Released the following year, ''[[If You Love This Planet]]'', winner of the [[Academy Awards|Academy Award]] for best documentary short subject, was labelled foreign propaganda under the [[Foreign Agents Registration Act|Foreign Agents Registration Act of 1938]] in the United States.The politicized Oscar. (political aspects of Academy Awards, 1983).Richard Grenier. Commentary 75.(June 1983): pp68(7). ==NFB on TV== The NFB is a minority owner of the digital television channel, [[Documentary (TV channel)|Documentary]] in Canada. NFB-branded series ''[[Retrovision]]'' appeared on VisionTV, along with the French-language ''Carnets ONF'' series on [[Aboriginal Peoples Television Network|APTN]]. Moreover, in 1997 the American cable channel [[Cartoon Network]] created a weekly 30-minute show called ''O Canada'' specifically showcasing a compilation of NFB-produced works; the segment was discontinued in favour of ''[[Adult Swim]]''.{{cite news|url=http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0JSF/is_16_6/ai_30214833 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20041127115831/http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0JSF/is_16_6/ai_30214833 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=November 27, 2004 |title=O Canada: Canadian animators |last=Simensky |first=Linda |authorlink=Linda Simensky |publisher=TAKE ONE |year=1997 |accessdate=August 30, 2006 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.toonarific.com/show.php?show_id=2666|title=O Canada|publisher=Toonarific Cartoons|accessdate=August 30, 2006}} As of 2010, many of the NFB children's shows are available on the children's IPTV service [http://www.amebatv.com Ameba]. ==Logo== [[File:Old National Film Board of Canada logo.png|thumb|98px|2002 version.]] The Board's logo consists of a standing stylized figure (originally green) with its arms wide upward. The arms are met by an arch that mirrors them. The round head in between then resembles a pupil, making the entire symbol appear to be an [[Human eye|eye]] with legs. Launched in 1969, the logo symbolized a vision of humanity and was called "Man Seeing / L'homme qui voit". It was designed by Georges Beaupré. It was updated in 2002 by the firm of Paprika Communications.http://www.canadiandesignresource.ca/officialgallery/?p=722 Canadian Design Resource ==NFB in popular media== *The [[Scotland|Scottish]] music act [[Boards of Canada]] takes its name from the NFB. *There have been three NFB references in ''[[The Simpsons]]'' as of June 2015: the episode "[[E-I-E-I-(Annoyed Grunt)]]", has the Simpson family watching a Zorro movie whose production is credited to the NFB,{{cite web|url=http://simpsonseh.com/simpsons/|title=Simpsons, Eh?|last=Penner|first=Wade|accessdate=August 30, 2006}}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} "[[The Fat and the Furriest]]" was inspired by the NFB documentary ''[[Project Grizzly (film)|Project Grizzly]]'', while "[[The Italian Bob]]" has the students of Bart's class watching a diversity film created by [[PBS]] in association with the National Film Board of Canada.{{cite web|url=http://blog.nfb.ca/blog/2015/06/08/nfb-pop-culture/|title=May The Force Be With—D’Oh! The NFB in Pop Culture|date=June 8, 2015|work=NFB Blog|accessdate=June 12, 2015}} *[[George Lucas]], who had attributed the origins of "[[the Force]] " to a 1963 abstract NFB film by [[Arthur Lipsett]] entitled ''[[21-87]]'',{{cite web|last = Silberman|first = Steve|title = Life After Darth|publisher = Wired|date = May 2005 |url=https://www.wired.com/wired/archive/13.05/lucas.html?pg=3}} went on to use the number 2187 as the cell number where Princess Leia was being detained in ''[[Star Wars (film)|Star Wars]]''. ==See also== *[[Cinema of Canada]] *[[Cinema of Quebec]] *''[[From NFB to Box-Office]]'' *[[Documentary Organization of Canada]] ==References== {{Reflist|3}} ==Further reading== *{{cite book |last=Evans |first=Gary |title=In the National Interest: A Chronicle of the {{space|2}}2 – [[OCLC]] | num_employees = | website = [http://www.picarta.nl/login/LNG=EN www.picarta.nl] }}The '''Nederlandse Centrale Catalogus''' ('''NCC''') is the official Dutch bibliographic catalog and metadata index system that links to and consolidates the catalogs of over 400 libraries in the [[Netherlands]]. == Scope == The NCC contains bibliographic data and locations of more than 14 million books and 500,000 [[magazines]] operating in more than 400 [[Netherlands]] [[Library|libraries]] are found. The database is updated by the libraries that participate in the Gemeenschappelijk Geautomatiseerd Catalogussysteem (GGC; ''Shared Automated Cataloguing System).'' The database is managed jointly by the [[National Library of the Netherlands]] (Koninklijke Bibliotheek – KB) and [[OCLC Online Computer Library Center, Inc.]] (OCLC), a non-profit global cooperative headquartered in [[Dublin, Ohio]]. The catalog data has been digitized and is openly accessible online, in multiple languages, ''via'' the Dutch website, [[PiCarta]] [[:nl:PiCarta|(nl)]]. A GGC identifier is synonymous with PPN (PICA Production Number), which derives its name from [[OCLC PICA|PICA]], makers of [[PiCarta]] [[:nl:PiCarta|(nl)]], the main producer of library systems in the Netherlands that was acquired in 2007 by OCLC. NCC, using OCLC technology, offers interlibrary loan among participating institutions, which includes Article Exchange — a [[cloud-based]] secure [[Image sharing|article sharing]] [[Computing platform|platform]] that automatically deletes articles after a specified number of downloads and number of days. == History == The NCC was founded in 1919 through the initiative of [[Philipp Christiaan Molhuysen]] [[:nl:Philipp Christiaan Molhuysen|(nl)]], PhD (1870–1944), librarian and biographer of the [[Dutch Royal Library]] and notable pioneer of [[library science]], who, among other things, spearheaded the first effort on record to centralize a catalog for all books in Dutch libraries. The initial effort culminated in massive collection [[Library catalog|catalog]] cards stored at the [[National Library of the Netherlands]] in [[The Hague]]. As a precursor for the launch, Molhuysen and Elsa Rachel Oppenheim (1885–1941) — his second of three wives — together, completed in 1916 the ''Catalogue de la Bibliothèque du Palais de la Paix,'' for the [[Peace Palace]] law library in [[The Hague]]. In the 1970s and 1980s, the indexing was migrated to digital formats, initially to the GGC, then to the NCC. File:P.C.Molhuysen.jpg|

{{distinguish|Portland Museum of Art}} {{Infobox Museum |name = Portland Art Museum |image = Portland Art Museum.jpg |established = 1892 |location = [[Portland, Oregon]],
United States |type = [[Private sector|private]]: [[art]] |visitors = 445,000 (2002)[http://otc.traveloregon.com/factsfigs/0303_TravelNews.pdf Travel Oregon] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070413153457/http://otc.traveloregon.com/factsfigs/0303_TravelNews.pdf |date=April 13, 2007 }} |director = Brian J. Ferriso |curator = |website = [http://portlandartmuseum.org/ portlandartmuseum.org] {{Infobox NRHP | embed = yes | name = Portland Art Museum | nrhp_type = | designated_other1_name = Portland Historic Landmark{{citation|author=Portland Historic Landmarks Commission|title=Historic Landmarks -- Portland, Oregon|format=XLS|date=July 2010|url=http://www.portlandonline.com/planning/index.cfm?c=44013&a=146276|accessdate=November 13, 2013}}. | designated_other1_color = lightgreen | image = | caption = | location= 1219 SW Park Avenue
[[Portland, Oregon]] | coordinates = {{coord|45.516211|-122.683515|region:US-OR_type:landmark|format=dms|display=inline,title}} | locmapin = Portland downtown | map_caption = Location within downtown Portland | built = 1932 | architect = [[Pietro Belluschi]] | added = December 31, 1974 | area = {{convert|1|acre}} | governing_body = private | refnum = 74001710{{NRISref|version=2010a}} }} }} The '''Portland Art Museum''' in [[Portland, Oregon]], United States, was founded in 1892, making it the oldest [[art museum]] on the [[West Coast of the United States|West Coast]] and seventh oldest in the US.{{cite web | title = About the Museum | publisher = Portland Art Museum | url = http://portlandartmuseum.org/about//history/ | accessdate = 2011-04-13}} Upon completion of the most recent renovations, the Portland Art Museum became one of the 25 largest art museums in the US, at a total of 240,000 square feet (22,000 m²), with more than 112,000 square feet (10,400 m²) of gallery space. The permanent collection has more than 42,000 works of art, and at least one major traveling exhibition is usually on show. The Portland Art Museum features a center for Native American art, a center for Northwest art, a center for modern and contemporary art, permanent exhibitions of Asian art, and an outdoor public sculpture garden. The [[Northwest Film Center]] is also a component of Portland Art Museum. The mission of the Portland Art Museum is to serve the public by providing access to art of enduring quality, by educating a diverse audience about art and by collecting and preserving a wide range of art for the enrichment of present and future generations.[http://web.pam.org/asp/templates/page.asp?pageID=75 Portland Art Museum Mission] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070628232411/https://web.pam.org/asp/templates/page.asp?pageID=75 |date=2007-06-28 }} The museum is accredited by the [[American Alliance of Museums]], with accreditation through 2024.[http://www.aam-us.org/docs/accreditation/list-of-accredited-museums.pdf?sfvrsn=4 List of Accredited Museums.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130117023703/http://aam-us.org/docs/accreditation/list-of-accredited-museums.pdf?sfvrsn=4 |date=2013-01-17 }} American Alliance of Museums. Retrieved December 13, 2007.{{cite news|last=Row|first=D.K.|title=Portland Art Museum renews accreditation from American Association of Museums|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/pacific-northwest-news/index.ssf/2011/04/portland_art_museum_renews_accreditation_from_american_association_of_museums.html|newspaper=The Oregonian|date=April 10, 2011}} ==Founding== Originally incorporated as the '''Portland Art Association''', the museum's roots date to 1892.{{Cite web|url=http://www.oregonencyclopedia.org/articles/portland_art_association/#.VywKABUrLsk|title=Portland Art Association|website=www.oregonencyclopedia.org|access-date=May 6, 2016}} Late that year seven prominent business and cultural leaders in the city created the association so as to start a high-quality art museum for a city approaching 50,000 residents. [[Henry Corbett]] donated $10,000 to the association that funded the museum's first collection (the Corbett Collection), which consisted of one hundred plaster casts of Greek and Roman sculptures. The individual pieces of the collection were selected by Winslow B. Ayer and his wife during a trip to Europe. They had been advised by curators at the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] in New York and the [[Museum of Fine Arts, Boston|Museum of Fine Arts]] in Boston prior to the trip on what pieces to select. The collection was originally displayed at the Multnomah County Library located at Southwest Seventh and [[Stark Street|Stark]] streets in Downtown. ==Early history== By the time of the [[Lewis & Clark Exposition]] held in Portland in 1905, the Portland Art Museum had outgrown its location in the public library and had moved into its own building at SW 5th and Taylor. The first exhibition in the new building featured watercolors and paintings that had come to Portland as part of the 1905 Exposition. Curator Henrietta H. Failing (the niece of founder [[Henry Failing]]) organized the exhibition with New England artist Frank Vincent DuMond. Three years later, in 1908, the museum acquired its first original piece of art, ''Afternoon Sky, Harney Desert'' by American impressionist painter [[Childe Hassam]], who frequented [[Malheur County, Oregon|Malheur]] and [[Harney County, Oregon|Harney]] counties in [[Eastern Oregon]] with his friend, [[C.E.S. Wood]]. Anna Belle Crocker succeeded Henrietta Failing as curator of the museum in 1909. She would remain at the museum until her retirement in 1936. Crocker became one of the Portland Art Museum's most important early figures. She was also the first head of the Museum Art School, which opened in 1909 and is now the [[Pacific Northwest College of Art]]. In late 1913, the museum hosted one of its most important early exhibitions. The exhibition featured artwork that had been on display earlier that year at the famous 1913 New York [[Armory Show]], which introduced American audiences to [[modern art]]. The exhibition included works by [[Paul Cézanne|Cézanne]], [[Van Gogh]], [[Paul Gauguin|Gauguin]], [[Matisse]], [[Manet]], [[Renoir]], and the controversial ''[[Nude Descending a Staircase]]'' by [[Marcel Duchamp]]. The museum continued to grow during the years following World War I. In the 1920s, the museum hosted two memorable exhibitions organized by Sally Lewis, the daughter of a prominent Portland family. Lewis had befriended many well-known artists on trips to New York and Europe. In 1923, Lewis organized an exhibition at the museum that included 44 paintings by [[Picasso]], Matisse, [[André Derain]] and American modernists, such as [[Maurice Prendergast]], [[Charles Burchfield]], and [[Max Weber (artist)|Max Weber]]. She was also one of 22 patrons who purchased Derain's ''Tree'' for the museum's permanent collection. The success of her first exhibition led to her second, more daring endeavor a year later that juxtaposed paintings, drawings, and sculptures from Europe with African masks. Among the sculptures was Brâncuși's ''A Muse'', which Lewis owned and donated to the museum in 1959. ==Main building== [[File:Portland Art Museum interior (September 2013) - 1.JPG|thumb|A staircase inside the museum]] The museum's final location opened to the public on November 18, 1932, at the corner of SW Park Avenue and Jefferson Street. The building, designed by noted Portland architect [[Pietro Belluschi]], is situated along downtown Portland's [[South Park Blocks]] and remains a landmark in the city's Cultural District. It was constructed with a lead gift of $100,000 from Winslow B. Ayer, the same patron who selected the museum's collection of plaster casts 40 years earlier. For this reason, the original portion of today's larger main building is referred to as the Ayer Wing. Barely six years later, construction began on a new wing to expand the main building. The Hirsch Wing, also designed by [[Pietro Belluschi]], was funded largely through the bequest of Ella Hirsch in honor of her parents, [[Solomon Hirsch|Solomon]] and Josephine Hirsch. The new wing opened on September 15, 1939 and doubled the museum's gallery space. ==Post war== In 1942, the Portland Art Museum celebrated a subdued 50th Anniversary due to World War II. But the following year in 1943, staff completed the museum's first full inventory, which counted a permanent collection of 3,300 objects and 750 works on long-term loan. The next decade was distinguished by a series of record-setting exhibitions. In 1956, nearly 55,000 visitors came to the museum during the six-week run of an exhibition featuring paintings from the collection of [[Walter Chrysler]]. The exhibition was organized by the Portland Art Museum and toured nine other cities. More than 80,000 people visited for a [[Vincent van Gogh]] exhibition in 1959, the proceeds from which were used to purchase ''[[Water Lilies]]'' by [[Claude Monet]]. The 1950s also witnessed the creation of the museum's Docent Council in 1955, which created a core group of volunteers who continue to serve the museum to this day. In the 1960s, the museum underwent another major renovation to build the Hoffman Memorial Wing, named for L. Hawley Hoffman, who served as president of the museum twice. Funded by the museum's first capital campaign, the new wing began construction in November 1968 and was finished in September 1970. Pietro Belluschi served as the architect again, and the project allowed him to realize a complete vision for the museum that he had conceived nearly 40 years earlier. The expansion created classroom and studio space for the Museum Art School, a sculpture mall, a new vault for the collections, and an auditorium. Over the course of the next several decades, the collections and programs of the Portland Art Museum continued to grow and evolve. In 1978, Vivian and [[Gordon Gilkey]] began their association with the museum, bringing with them an extraordinary collection of thousands of works on paper that would eventually lead to the opening of the Vivian and Gordon Gilkey Center for Graphic Arts in 1993. Also in 1978, the [[Northwest Film Center]] was incorporated into the museum, offering a wide range of film festivals, classes, and outreach programs focused on the moving image arts. ==Modern era== [[File:Portland Art Museum Mark Building - Oregon.JPG|thumb|PAM's [[Mark Building]]]] The Portland Art Museum celebrated its centennial in 1992, which was marked by successful negotiations to purchase the Masonic Temple, now known as the [[Mark Building]].{{cite news|title=The Latest Buzz on Our Big Sister City|last=Nicholas|first=Jonathan|date=1992-01-30|work=The Oregonian|pages=D01}} The purchase was completed in 1994, the same year that a capital campaign to finance a refurbishment of the Main Building began. This ambitious project included improving the galleries, reinstalling the permanent collection, and equipping the building with a climate control system. The refurbishment allowed the museum to host the most successful exhibition in its history: Imperial Tombs of China, which brought 430,000 visitors to the museum the following year. A major renovation of the Hoffman Wing was completed in 2000 and added more than {{convert|50000|sqft|m2|-3}} of new gallery space to the museum. The first gallery space addition since 1939, the new galleries included the Grand Ronde Center for Native American Art and the Arlene and Harold Schnitzer Center for Northwest Art. The renovation was funded by the largest capital campaign ever undertaken by a cultural organization in the State of Oregon, which raised $45 million. In 2001, the Portland Art Museum announced the largest single acquisition in its history when it purchased the private collection of renowned New York art critic [[Clement Greenberg]]. The 159 works by artists such as [[Kenneth Noland]], [[Jules Olitski]], and [[Anthony Caro]] substantially enhanced the museum's permanent collection of 20th century modern and contemporary art. To house this new collection, the museum renovated the former Masonic temple, transforming it into the {{convert|141000|sqft|m2|-2|sing=on}} Mark Building, which opened in October 2005. The renovation added the six-floor, {{convert|28000|sqft|m2|-2|sing=on}} Jubitz Center for Modern and Contemporary Art, the largest exhibition space for modern and contemporary art in the region. The Mark Building also houses the 33,000 volume Crumpacker Family Library, meeting spaces, ballrooms, and administrative offices. Now with a collection consisting of some 40,000 objects, the Portland Art Museum is one of the leading cultural institutions in the Pacific Northwest. The museum is currently under the leadership of Brian Ferriso, The Marilyn H. and Dr. [[Robert B. Pamplin, Jr.]] Director since 2006. In 2007, [[Vincent van Gogh]]'s 1884 painting ''[[Cart with Black Ox|The Ox-Cart]]'' was donated to the museum, becoming the first work of that artist in a Northwest museum.Row, D.K. [http://www.oregonlive.com/entertainment/oregonian/index.ssf?/base/entertainment/119250333584990.xml&coll=7 Portland Art Museum gets NW's first van Gogh.] ''[[The Oregonian]]'', October 15, 2007. Beginning in December 2013, [[Francis Bacon (artist)|Francis Bacon]]'s ''[[Three Studies of Lucian Freud]]'' went on display for three months shortly after it was sold at auction at the highest price ever paid for a work of art.{{cite news|last=Stabler|first=David|title=Art of darkness: Francis Bacon's record-breaking triptych at Portland Art Museum finds beauty in bleakness|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2014/01/art_of_darkness_francis_bacons.html|accessdate=14 January 2014|newspaper=The Oregonian|date=January 8, 2014}} In 2016, the Portland Art Museum announced that it will undertake a glass-walled expansion to unite its two existing free-standing buildings. The addition, to be called the Rothko Pavilion, comes with a partnership with [[Mark Rothko]]’s children, Christopher Rothko and Kate Rothko Prizel, that will provide loans of major Rothko paintings from their private collection. The works will be lent individually in rotation over the course of the next two decades.Randy Kennedy (October 8, 2016), [https://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/08/arts/design/mark-rothko-portland-museum-of-art-rothko-pavilion-new-wing.html Mark Rothko, Son of Oregon, to Be Honored With Museum Wing] ''[[New York Times]]''. ==Artworks== [[File:The Ox Cart by Vincent van Gogh - Portland Art Museum.JPG|thumb|Vincent van Gogh's ''The Ox Cart'']] The museum has a collection of over 40,000 objects and works of art. Among them: *''Castel Gandolfo'' by [[George Inness]] – The American Art Collection, *''Mount Hood'' by [[Albert Bierstadt]] – The American Art Collection, *''The finding of Moses'' (av. 1730) by [[Giambattista Pittoni]] *''Arrival of the Westerners'' by Kano School ([[Edo period|Edo-period]] screen) – The Asian Art Collection, *''Paris: Quai de Bercy — La Halle aux Vins'' by [[Paul Cézanne]] – The Modern and Contemporary Art Collection, *''[[Water Lilies]]'' by [[Claude Monet]] – The Modern and Contemporary Art Collection, *''The Prince Patutszky Red'' by [[Jules Olitski]] – The Modern and Contemporary Art Collection *''Seine at Argentieul'' by Pierre Renoir *''River at Lavacourt'' by Claude Monet *''[[Cart with Black Ox|The Ox-Cart]]'' by [[Vincent van Gogh]] *''Nativity'' by [[Taddeo Gaddi]] *''Madonna and Child'' by [[Cecco di Pietro]] *''Allegory Figure of Woman'' by Franz Von Stuck *''Top of The Town'' by Roger Brown *''A Muse'' by Constantin Brâncuși ==Oregon Biennial== The '''Oregon Biennial''' was a [[wikt:biennale|biennial]] [[art exhibition]] held every two years at PAM.[http://web.pam.org/asp/special_exhibitions/exhibitions.asp?exhibitionID=37 Portland Art Museum Special Exhibitions: 2006 Biennial] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927095352/http://web.pam.org/asp/special_exhibitions/exhibitions.asp?exhibitionID=37 |date=2007-09-27 }} In 2007, it was replaced by the Contemporary Northwest Art Awards or CNAA, which will be held every two years and covers artists in Oregon, Washington, Idaho, Wyoming and Montana selected from a shortlist of artists. One artist from the CNAA show will be awarded the $10,000 Arlene Schnitzer Prize.[http://www.portlandart.net/archives/2007/04/goodby_oregon_b.html Goodbye Oregon Biennial, Hello CNAA] ==Crumpacker Family Library== The Crumpacker Family Library, founded with the museum in 1892, contains over 40,000 catalogued items. The library is open to researchers by appointment, with computers and wireless internet available for use. Visitors can view past Museum lectures and artist videos in the media room. Reference help is available via phone, email, or in-person visits. The library is located on the second floor of the Mark Building, and is open Monday through Thursday from noon until five PM by appointment only.https://portlandartmuseum.org/learn/crumpacker-family-library/ ==References== {{Reflist|2}} == External links == {{Commons category|Portland Art Museum}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070521093434/http://portlandartmuseum.org/exhibitions/rembrandt/ Rembrandt and the Golden Age of Dutch Art: Treasures from the Rijksmuseum] Portland Art Museum Special Exhibition {{National Register of Historic Places Oregon}} [[Category:1892 establishments in Oregon]] [[Category:Art museums established in 1892]] [[Category:Art museums in Oregon]] [[Category:Buildings and structures completed in 1932]] [[Category:FRAME Museums]] [[Category:Institutions accredited by the American Alliance of Museums]] [[Category:Museums in Portland, Oregon]] [[Category:National Register of Historic Places in Portland, Oregon]] [[Category:Pietro Belluschi buildings]] [[Category:Asian art museums in the United States]] [[Category:Portland Art Museum| ]] [[Category:Southwest Portland, Oregon]] [[Category:Portland Historic Landmarks]]

{{for|the United States pro-war Left|liberal hawk}} {{Multiple issues| {{original research|date=February 2009}} {{refimprove|date=May 2011}} }}
The '''pro-War Left''' was a grouping of [[United Kingdom|British]] [[left wing]] [[journalists]] and [[blog]]gers who supported for the [[2003 invasion of Iraq]], at variance with much of the rest of the British [[Left-wing politics|left]] which opposed it. They were centered on the [[Euston manifesto]].<ref name=euston>[http://eustonmanifesto.org/joomla/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=12&Itemid=41 "The Euston Manifesto"], March 29, 2006.</ref> which in October 2007 had 2,929 signatories. The name is derived from the pro-war group the Undertakers.
They have some similarity with US [[Liberal hawks]] and [[Anti-Germans (political current)|Anti-Germans]].
==Supporters== The Pro-War Left can be seen as mainly a phenomenon of the [[blogosphere]]. Most of its supporters contribute to or run blogs, ''[[Harry's Place]]'' being the most well known and influential of these.
On October 7, 2007, a counter-demonstration<ref>[http://hurryupharry.bloghouse.net/archives/2007/10/08/pictures_from_the_al_quds_counter_demo.php]{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} From the Harry's place blog</ref> to the [[Al-Quds]] march was organised by Harry’s Place to which all the Pro-War Left were invited. The organisers estimate that 100 people turned up over the course of the day.
As well as the Euston Manifesto there are other organisations that have been associated with the Pro-War Left such as [[Labour Friends of Iraq]], [[Unite Against Terror]], [[Democratiya]] and [[Engage (organization)|Engage]].
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090928000111/http://www.neoconeurope.eu/Decent_Left Decent Left], Neocon Europe profile. * [[Norman Geras]], [http://commentisfree.guardian.co.uk/norman_geras/2006/04/introducing_the_euston_manifes.html Introducing the Euston Manifesto], ''The Guardian'', 13 April 2006. * Norman Geras and [[Nick Cohen]], [http://www.newstatesman.com/200604170006 The Euston Manifesto], New Statesman, 17 April 2006. * [[Geoffrey Wheatcroft]], [https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/story/0,,1771475,00.html They should come out as imperialist and proud of it: There is a progressive tradition of support for colonialism, which the Euston manifesto group could champion], The Guardian, 10 May 2006. * Norman Geras, [https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/story/0,,1782407,00.html The path out of denial], The Guardian, 25 May 2006. * [[Mike Marqusee]], [https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2006/apr/14/moralquicksandofmoralhighg The moral quicksand of the moral high ground], Comment is Free, guardian.co.uk, 14 April 2006. * [[DD Guttenplan]], [http://commentisfree.guardian.co.uk/dd_guttenplan/2006/04/no_sects_pleaseyoure_british.html.printer.friendly No sects please, you're British], ''The Guardian'', 17 April 2006. * Daniel Davies, [http://commentisfree.guardian.co.uk/daniel_davies/2008/04/next_stop_is_euston_where_this.html Next stop Euston. This manifesto terminates here], ''The Guardian'', 14 April 2008 * [[Alan Johnson]], [https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2008/apr/21/theeustonmoment The Euston Moment], guardian.co.uk, 21 April 2008.
